title: Recent study
text: In a recent study with nearly 300 adults seeking mental health counseling, participants were divided into 3 groups - write one letter of gratitude to another person each week for three weeks, no writing activity, or write their feelings about negative experiences. Those who wrote gratitude letters reported significantly better mental health outcomes 4 and 12 weeks later. This suggests that integrating gratitude practice, no matter how brief, with counseling can provide even greater benefits for mental well-being, especially for individuals dealing with mental health concerns. It's a powerful reminder of the transformative impact of gratitude, offering a simple yet effective way to enhance emotional resilience and overall well-being, even in the face of challenges like depression and anxiety. ðŸ’¡ So here is a new note jar idea for you - write one letter of gratitude to another person each week and see the results for yourself.
author: Summary from a research by Joshua Brown and Joel Wong
